column1: The War in Donbass is an armed conflict in the Donbass region of Ukraine
column2: part of the Ukrainian crisis and the broader Russo-Ukrainian War. From the beginning of March 2014
column3: in the aftermath of the 2014 Ukrainian revolution and the Euromaidan movement
column4: protests by Russia-backed anti-government separatist groups took place in the Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts of Ukraine
column5: collectively called the "Donbass". These demonstrations
column6: which followed the February–March 2014 annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation
column7: and which were part of a wider group of concurrent protests across southern and eastern Ukraine
column8: escalated into an armed conflict between the separatist forces of the self-declared Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics (DPR and LPR respectively)
column9: and the Ukrainian government. While the initial protests were largely native expressions of discontent with the new Ukrainian government
column10: Russia took advantage of them to launch a co-ordinated political and military campaign against Ukraine. Russians citizens led the separatist movement in Donetsk from April until August 2014
column11: and were supported by volunteers and materiel from Russia. As the conflict escalated in May 2014
column12: Russia employed a "hybrid approach"
column13: deploying a combination of disinformation tactics
column14: irregular fighters
column15: regular Russian troops
column16: and conventional military support to destabilise the Donbass region. According to the Ukrainian government
column17: at the height of the conflict in the summer of 2014
column18: Russian paramilitaries were reported to make up between 15% to 80% of the combatants.Ukraine launched a military counter-offensive against pro-Russian forces in April 2014
column19: called the "Anti-Terrorist Operation" (ATO) from 2014 until 2018
column20: when it was renamed the "Joint Forces Operation" (JFO). By late August 2014 this operation was able to vastly shrink the territory under the control of the pro-Russian forces
column21: and came close to regaining control of the Russo-Ukrainian border. In response
column22: Russia abandoned its hybrid approach
column23: and began a conventional invasion of the Donbass. Between 22 and 25 August 2014
column24: Russian artillery
column26: and what Russia called a "humanitarian convoy" crossed the border into Ukrainian territory without permission of the Ukrainian government. Crossings occurred both in areas under the control of pro-Russian forces and in areas that were not under their control
column27: such as the south-eastern part of Donetsk Oblast
column28: near Novoazovsk. These events followed the reported shelling of Ukrainian positions from the Russian side of the border over the course of the preceding month. Head of the Security Service of Ukraine
column29: Valentyn Nalyvaichenko characterised the events of 22 August as a "direct invasion by Russia of Ukraine"
column30: while other western and Ukrainian officials described the events as a "stealth invasion" of Ukraine by Russia. Russia's official position on the presence of Russian forces in Donbass has been vague: while official bodies have denied presence of "regular armed forces" in Ukraine
column31: it has on numerous occasions confirmed presence of "military specialists"
column33: usually accompanied by an argument that Russia "was forced" to deploy them to "defend the Russian-speaking population".As a result of the invasion
column34: DPR and LPR insurgents regained much of the territory they had lost during the Ukrainian government's preceding military offensive. Ukraine
column36: the DPR and the LPR signed an agreement to establish a ceasefire
column38: on 5 September 2014. Violations of the ceasefire on both sides became common. Amidst the solidification of the line between insurgent and government-controlled territory during the ceasefire
column39: warlords took control of swaths of land on the insurgent side
column40: leading to further destabilisation. The ceasefire completely collapsed in January 2015
column41: with renewed heavy fighting across the conflict zone
column42: including at Donetsk International Airport and at Debaltseve. Involved parties agreed to a new ceasefire
column44: on 12 February 2015. Immediately following the signing of the agreement
column45: separatist forces launched an offensive on Debaltseve and forced Ukrainian forces to withdraw from it. In the months after the fall of Debaltseve
column46: minor skirmishes continued along the line of contact
column47: but no territorial changes occurred. This state of stalemate led to the war being labelled a "frozen conflict"; despite this
column48: the area remained a war zone
column49: with dozens of soldiers and civilians killed each month. In 2017
column50: on average one Ukrainian soldier died in combat every three days
column51: with the number of Russian and separatist troops remaining in the region estimated at 6

OSCE has also documented numerous cases of military convoys crossing from the Russian Federation into the occupied territory on dirt roads away from official border crossings and usually during the night.Since the start of the conflict there have been 29 ceasefires

column1: == Background ==
=== Donetsk Oblast ===
Attempts to seize the Donetsk Regional State Administration (RSA) building began since pro-Russian protests erupted in the eastern and southern regions of Ukraine
column2: in the wake of the 2014 Ukrainian revolution. Pro-Russian protesters occupied the Donetsk RSA from 1 to 6 March 2014
column3: before being removed by the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU). On 6 April
column6: 000 people gathered at a rally in Donetsk to demand a status referendum similar to the one held in Crimea in March. The demonstrators stormed the RSA building
column7: and took control of its first two floors. They said that if an extraordinary legislative session was not held by regional officials to implement a status referendum
column8: they would take control of the regional government with a "people's mandate"
column9: and dismiss all elected regional councillors and members of parliament. As these demands were not met
column10: the activists held a meeting in the RSA building
column11: and voted in favour of independence from Ukraine. They proclaimed the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) on 7 April 2014.

column1: === Luhansk Oblast ===
Unrest in Luhansk Oblast began on 6 April
column2: when approximately 1
column3: 000 activists seized and occupied the SBU building in the city of Luhansk
column4: following similar occupations in the cities of Donetsk and Kharkiv. Protesters barricaded the building
column5: and demanded that all arrested separatist leaders be released. Police were able to retake control of the building
column6: but the demonstrators regathered for a 'people's assembly' outside the building and called for a 'people's government'
column7: demanding either federalisation or incorporation into the Russian Federation. At this assembly
column8: they elected Valery Bolotov to the position of "People's Governor". Two referendums were announced
column9: one on 11 May to determine whether the region should seek some form of autonomy
column10: and a second scheduled for 18 May to determine whether the region should join the Russian Federation
column11: or declare independence. The Luhansk People's Republic (LPR) was declared on 27 April. Representatives of the Republic demanded that Ukrainian government provide amnesty for all protesters
column12: enshrine Russian as an official language
column13: and hold a referendum on the status of the region. They issued an ultimatum that stated that if Kyiv did not meet their demands by 14:00 on 29 April
column14: they would launch an insurgency in tandem with that of the Donetsk People's Republic.

column4: took part in the seizure on the separatists' side. After having gained control of the Donetsk RSA and having declared the Donetsk People's Republic
column5: pro-Russian groups vowed to fan out and take control of strategic infrastructure across Donetsk Oblast
column6: and demanded that public officials who wished to continue their work swear allegiance to the Republic. By 14 April
column7: pro-Russian militants led by former GRU operatives Igor Girkin and Igor Bezler had taken control of government buildings in many other cities within the oblast
column8: including Sloviansk
column9: Mariupol
column10: Horlivka
column11: Kramatorsk
column12: Yenakiieve
column13: Makiivka
column14: Druzhkivka
column15: and Zhdanivka. Following this seizure of the Donetsk RSA
column16: the militants began to expand their control across the city. The municipal administration building was stormed and occupied by the insurgents on 16 April. Further actions by the separatists resulted in the capture of the offices of the regional state television network on 27 April. After capturing the broadcasting centre
column17: the militants began to broadcast Russian television channels. On 4 May
column18: the flag of the Donetsk People's Republic was raised over the police headquarters in Donetsk city proper.A number of interviews given in 2019–2020 by participants on the Russian side (including Girkin
column19: Bezler
column20: Gubarev and others) revealed that the initial idea to take control of Donbass towns was passed on to Donetsk "People's Governor" Pavel Gubarev by Sergey Glazyev

Military and financial support for the group was provided by Sergey Aksyonov and Konstantin Malofeev. Novaya Gazeta summarised the situation as "a group of poorly prepared mercenaries turning a whole region into a bloodbath" and concluded that Russia "will bear moral and political responsibility for its civilian casualties as long as its participants are not taken to court".In response to the widening unrest

==== Sloviansk ====

column5: on 12 April. After militants took over the city
column6: Sloviansk mayor Nelya Shtepa briefly appeared at an occupied police station
column7: and expressed support for the militants. Others gathered outside the building
column8: and similarly voiced their support for the militants. They told Ukrainian journalists who were reporting on the situation to "go back to Kyiv". Nelya Shtepa was later detained by the insurgents
column9: and replaced by the self-proclaimed "people's mayor" Vyacheslav Ponomarev. The militants gained control of the city's police weapons cache and seized hundreds of firearms

Militants attempted to seize the police headquarters in Horlivka on 12 April

column3: however

Donetsk People's Republic activists took control of the city administration building in Mariupol on 13 April. The Ukrainian government claimed to have "liberated" the building on 24 April

column4: leading the Ukrainian government to send in military forces. Skirmishes between the troops and local demonstrators caused the city administration building to be set on fire. Government forces
column5: however

=== Ukrainian public opinion ===

A poll of the Ukrainian public, excluding Russian-annexed Crimea, was taken by the International Republican Institute from 12–25 September 2014. 89% of those polled opposed Russian intervention in Ukraine. As broken down by region, 78% of those polled from Eastern Ukraine (including Dnipropetrovsk Oblast) opposed said intervention, along with 89% in Southern Ukraine, 93% in Central Ukraine, and 99% in Western Ukraine. As broken down by native language, 79% of Russian speakers and 95% of Ukrainian speakers opposed the intervention. 80% of those polled said that Ukraine should remain a unitary country. 56% of those polled said that Russia should pay for the reconstruction of the Donbass, whereas 32% said Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts should pay. 59% of those polled said that they supported the government military operation in Donbass, whereas 33% said that they opposed it. 73% of respondents said that the war in Donbass was one of the three most important issues facing Ukraine.A poll conducted by the same institute in 2017 shows that an overwhelming majority of Ukrainians believe that the separatist republics should remain as part of Ukraine. The survey contained an over sample of respondents from the Ukrainian-controlled areas of the Donbass, a majority of whom also affirmed their wish for the entire region to stay in Ukraine. The survey results showed that 80% of Ukrainians nationally and 73% of people living in the Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts supported that the separatist-controlled areas should remain part of Ukraine. Around 60% of the people polled did not believe Ukraine is doing enough to regain the lost territories because of the Minsk agreements.
